In this game, you are laying down tiles in a big grid. There are a few placement rules, but the focus is on the fact that when you put a tile down into a chain of tiles, a player who's marker is a part of that chain, with the matching color, gets a cube in that color. When two cities connect, or when a player puts a marker down in the same city as a matching opponent's marker, then players battle by spending randomly drawn tiles from behind their player screen of the color of the conflict, with the most tiles winning. In some cases you also count tiles around your marker, and in some you don't but I found the combat incredibly frustrating. My opponents might win a combat without spending any tiles behind their screen, and then I lost a combat where I had a +5 advantage to someone revealing 5 matching tiles. The winner of the combat gets some cube payout in the matching color as well.

When someone loses a combat, parts of the city flay off, which means your positions can get messed up even through no participation of your own.

A game that painfully shows it age. I've seen this game referred to as a masterpiece, I'd say the only masterful thing about it is the astonishing lack of player agency and pace this game presents, all while defiantly occupying your table for 2 hours.

The worst thing about this experience was the downtime. AP is strong here since the option space is wide and there are any number of different combinations of moves you can make each turn, and since the scoring system is tricky you'll find that players agonise over every single move, dragging the game down to the most glacial of velocities.

Since the tiles you place are directly responsible for your score, it is pretty annoying that you only get to draw them randomly from a bag. You can exchange your hand, sure, but it costs you an action and probably the game if you do this more than once. Every turn consists of you drawing tiles, and realising that you either scored nothing that turn or completely wrecked your opponents that turn. This kind of randomness is fine in most games, I've nothing against it in principle, but this is a strategy game and a pretty long one at that.

I feel that if players had more agency over their hand of tiles then this could be a lot of fun. Playing a huge turn which swings the board in your favour would give you a nice opportunity to pat yourself on the back for being a clever little sausage and would reward delicate planning. As the game comes, though, you have precious few turns in which anything of real consequence happens, and the games drags.

Tigris and Euphrates is a problematic game hampered by poorly written unintuitive rules that encumber fairly simple game concepts. Like many eurogames, the winner is unclear until resolving how the resources have been accumulated.

As a caveat to those with an interest in ancient history or Civilization type games, the ancient civilization shtick is just a veneer, included to add artistic appeal to the game. OTOH the components and art are nice.

I'd recommend this game for folks who like puzzle solving games. I'd warn away folks who intend on playing anything light and fun or social.

I house ruled the game quite a bit and made it a bit more fun. I got rid of the revolt mechanics, and only let one player occupy a particular kingdom. Tiles had to be placed next to other friendly tiles. Catastrophe tiles had to be purchased with victory point tokens (4 of the same or 8 mixed). Attacks take a full player action phase and require a temple tile place between the two kingdoms to initiate. During wars each kingdom tallies the number of temple tiles on the board and can add temple tiles in their hand. The loser must remove their leader as well as all temple tiles from the defeated kingdom (as well as any orphan tiles that are no longer adjacent to friendly tiles). Finally I added a trade phase, where players were free to trade victory point tokens with each other. I found that this added a fun social aspect to the game (faintly similar to Diplomacy).

The fact that tiles get removed from the board during wars makes T & E fundamentally different than a lot of tile-laying games. I should like this game so much more than I do.

Pros:
A lot of people with similar tastes as I consider this game to be amazing, and I can totally see why.

There are so many great ideas in this game. The point system is brilliant because it's a very simple way to keep you from resting on your laurels. The conflicts are always tense and interesting, it has smartly built-in catch-up mechanisms and the way it forces you to fight and outwit your opponents is wonderful.

For example, the little trick of giving an opponent a monument to reduce their strength and then immediately take it over is a wonderfully devilish emergent gameplay moment.

The turn structure is very simple...

Cons:
...but the rules are actually deceptively complicated. The distinction between internal and external conflict may make sense thematically but I always have to look up turn order and how points are awarded and how the board is affected. I also feel like it's harder than it should be to determine strength and the board is just a little hard to read at times. There's also several sources of points and it's not always intuitive how to catch up a color deficiency for newer players.

My biggest problem is that I don't like the tile drawing. For one it's fiddly to have everyone draw from the same bag after a conflict. I also often feel very limited by my hand, where I want to do a play but my hand doesn't let me. I know that I can play better to manage my hand and e.g. waste tiles in a conflict as a free redraw, and I also know that good players should just play their hand instead of blaming poor draws. Still, I simply don't feel this way in Babylonia or Race for the Galaxy but I do here so obviously there's something to it.

The player order is also a bit too important for my liking. I don't like how you can be handed "free" stuff by simply playing after a big conflict and I don't like how not everyone gets the same number of turns in a way that's not in any way compensated for.

I think the game would feel less random and less fiddly if everyone had their own equally (or perhaps not depending on the player order) distributed bags of tiles like in Babylonia, but who am I to question the great Dr. Knizia?

I can definitely see why people love it and if I had a group dedicated to learning this game properly I'm sure we'd have a lot of fun. As it is now I think it's a fine game, but not one I'd choose to play.

I had no idea what I was doing in the game I've played, but I can still tell how expertly designed this game is. It's like the modern Go, fairly straightforward rules but incredibly brain burny with a place a piece for area control aspect. The different colors makes you have to consider different modes of play by your opponents, while the scoring of your minimum color score makes it so you can't just spam one color. Like Go where you place your tiles is not immediately apparent all the ramifications it has, which adds layers of strategy, but also potentially AP. The random tile draw while some might not like the randomness adds some hand management aspects to the game while presumably making the start of the game more variable, and there is a mulligan action (which is not a complete wasted turn, you can also use it to stock up on a color you want or rush the end of the game). Overall seamlessly combines all of its mechanisms together (albeit very abstractly) into a game that I can understand why there are many proponents that it should be ranked #1.

Highly group dependent, tense area control game that leaves you at the tip of your toes all the time, if you find the right group.

Luck of the draw can be harsh when you keep losing battles and/or leadership contests and can't bring your leaders back into good positions, which soured many in my group to not want to play again. The wide open play area is also something that many struggle with to make sense of where to invest and where to contest. This leaves T&E at the uncontested top spot of games with the most inconsistent game experiences.

Some sessions are an absolute joy, with different players approaching point acquisitions quite differently, sometimes with more than 5 monuments being build, other times with constant fights. However, other sessions left players hating it so much that it ruined the fun of game night for everyone at the table (and it's not because they don't like neg. interaction in games).

I’m downgrading this to a 5 as recent plays just have not matched the fun and enjoyment of its redesign Yellow & Yangtze, which just feels cleaner, more intuitive and more interesting. Y&Y’s hex board provides more variability for leader strength and gets to the heart of temple construction quicker. Having wars decided only by solider tiles just makes things so much more streamlined and the differentiation between tile colours is more prominent, making choices more meaningful as one plays colours not just for the score but for the powers they provide. T&E will live on in the hearts of the purists - and for good reason - but sometimes classics are redone in the right way and this case is such an example. Though maybe that’s slightly undeserved praise considering I play Y&Y with my variant Pagoda rules, but I don’t think I will play T&E again - it just felt too unintelligible by comparison.

There’s a certain level of unease—complete with wide-eyed surprise and a hint of terror—when someone mentions “take-that” mechanics or direct conflict between players. This reaction likely stems from the fact that many people prefer positive interactions over aggressive stances toward others. Yet, beneath this apprehension lies a benefit: players are incentivized to stay on guard or even adopt a more proactive approach. *Tigris & Euphrates*, for instance, is an intricate puzzle where every move demands careful calculation. While it could arguably be streamlined in parts (conflicts are divided into internal and external types), it’s not a game for those prone to analysis paralysis, nor is it suitable for every mood. Still, it offers a deeply rewarding—if occasionally frustrating—experience, much like life itself.

This has a timeless feel to it, almost as if it could’ve been born from the era it depicts. There’s also an epic sense to what’s happening on the board, which unfolds in ways that are fascinating and impossible to predict, telling a story in the process. Every turn is interesting, and things can quickly shift between feeling like you have a little time to advance your long term strategy, and being forced to address an immediate issue. Like other highly interactive games, this is best played between players of equal ability, but it’s especially true here because of how much the game can change from a single conflict, which may have originated from a single tile lay, or lack thereof. The game becomes less opaque with experience, but definitely reaches a plateau, where true understanding remains over the horizon.

T&E is my Platonic ideal of a board game. The play is with the other players, not the game itself. No min-maxing. No workers to place. Seasoned with a splash of hidden information and a dash of luck, the game is not the dry abstract you might have been led to believe. The theme - rise and fall of kingdoms - comes through with time.

Almost exclusively played online.

I've got rather late to this classic and Knizia games in general (I've missed many of them out in the 90s). Then however T&E jumped up into my very top games immediately. I've learned the game via the app, which - despite its mediocrity - managed to get me enthusiastic. The real experience is even more fantastic.

A shame that in my gaming groups T&E's popularity is low, because they prefer to have more theme in their strategy games, more simplicity in their abstract games, more balance in their random tile draws.

There is luck in tile draws, an ongoing lack of red tiles will only get you that far. Imo the game is less elegant than some Knizia fans claim it to be (in fact I perceive learning and to some degree also playing the game as somewhat unintuitive). But it's also way more thematic than some non-Knizia fans give it credit to. What I love about the game is that T&E tells stories. It's a dynamic ebb and flow of kingdoms and conflicts. Plays are packed with a mixture of strategy, tactics and board changing drama. Things have impact and you can feel that impact.

It's hard to put into words what attracts and fascinates me about this game.
The butterfly effect ? Every tile placed on the board potentially resonates for eternity (until the end of the game!), every move is therefore fraught with consequences, and what seemed like just a small green tile placed at the beginning of the game could end up winning the big war at the end.
The tension between building eternal monuments and exposing myself to war? Delving into the desert in search of forgotten treasures, but taking the risk of a catastrophe that would easily split the kingdom in two? Where should I place my leaders... Do I try to isolate myself or do I join different kingdoms? Foment a revolt? Prepare for a war whose outcome is more than uncertain? How can I turn the tide in my favor... and achieve the impossible with the tiles granted to me by the ancient Mesopotamian gods?

The famous final scoring seals the deal; this game is the special one for me.

Finally played again after having played it years ago and it blew my mind. It's a simple game with a very open beginning and if you don't play it often, knowing what to do in the early stages is not immediate. It's a one of a kind design and it really moved me quite deeply. It amazes me to know that something soo beautiful came out of a human mind. I can't wait to play it more and more so I can understand the layers of depth hidden within it!

It's what I call an elegant game - Everything is tied to area influence and points. There is very little strategic aspect but a lot of going with your gut feeling. It I especially like openness, the intuitive and bewildering gameplay as well as the hidden information. Players are taking risks and picking conflicts. Ther are incentives for peaceful expansion, alliances and aggression. The way how conflict arises and kingdoms ebb and flow makes for a surprising dynamic game. It may appear dry at first glance, but has a strong conceptual core and much is emerging from play.

In this video Dr. Rainer Knizia talks about the design and thematic considerations. I would not consider myself the biggest fan of Knizia games, but his design ethos gives me a very good feeling personally.

On the FFG version: The components are great, as is expected. Points are cardboard chits instead of wooden cubes. Leaders and monuments are made of plastic and they lose their iconic look and feel. Compared to the 1st edition (Hans im Glück) and 2nd edition (Pegasus) FFG provides a nice balance of playability, variability and is graphically effective.
